awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Phylogenetic and Functional Diversity of Tripartite Plant-Fungal-Bacterial Symbioses
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates the diversity, evolution and ecological functions within a diverse lineage of fungi, the Mucoromycota. These fungi are industrially important for lipid production and as biofertilizers in agricultural systems. They have co-evolved with plants through innovations of their growth within plant tissues, and are implicated in the successful invasion of land by plants. Many of the fungi in this group are plant growth promoters and carry within their cells bacterial endosymbionts belonging to lineages of bacteria that are known only from these fungi. Some of these bacteria produce potent toxins. This research investigates the role of these endobacteria on their fungal host's growth and metabolism, and the impact of endobacteria on fungal-plant interactions. It will produce a culture collection and database of these fungi available to other scientists.  Reference DNA barcodes and genome sequences from these collections will be integrated into sequence-based classifiers as a resource for the broader community. A short-course on "Computational Thinking in Biodiversity and Evolutionary Research", and studies to determine how traditional agriculture and cultural practices impact Mucoromycota fungi in the soil are part of the project. Overall, this research will provide diverse and cross-disciplinary education, training, and outreach to postdocs, graduate and undergraduate students.

The researchers will compare and analyze entire genomes to identify symbiosis traits that have co-evolved in plant-fungi-bacteria partners, and will assess the impact of bacterial endosymbionts on the function of their fungal host and its interaction with plants through metatranscriptomics. Changes in host plant phenotype, metabolome, transcriptome, and resilience to abiotic stress will be studied in experiments designed to test genetic traits in the host, fungi and bacteria. The phylogenetic dimension will integrate evolution and genomics to provide a robust phylogenomic framework and new computational tools for estimating co-evolutionary and horizontal gene transfer processes between Mucoromycota and their bacterial endosymbionts. The genetic dimension will apply genomic and metatranscriptomic studies of plant-fungal-bacterial symbionts, selected with guidance provided by the phylogenomics, to identify critical genes involved in symbiotic interactions. The functional component will dissect the role of candidate genes for plant host fitness in the context of different plant-fungal/bacterial partners and abiotic stressors. Together this integrated research will foster interdisciplinary collaborations to provide novel insights into the diversity, evolution and functioning of tripartite multi-kingdom symbiosis.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this research was to define phylogenetic and functional diversity, and evolutionary signatures of tripartite ‘plant-fungal-bacterial’ symbioses. Specifically, we aimed to (1) examine the phylogenomic diversity of early diverging plant-associated fungi in the Mucoromycota, and their endobacteria; (2) investigate global transcriptional and metabolic changes induced by fungal-plant-bacterial symbiosis; (3) assess the function of early diverging plant-associated Mucoromycota fungi and their endobacteria on plant-host fitness and function; and (4) develop a novel computational framework for inferring co-phylogenies using large-scale genomic sequence datasets with complex evolutionary histories.

This project was successful across all 4 aims. The revisionary systematics of Endogones and Mortierellales resulting from this project revised phylogenetically-based taxonomy of these two early-diverging plant-associated fungal lineages. We sequenced >20 high quality genomes from Mortierellaceae and their endobacteria, and generated genomic data from another >130 diverse taxa including from type specimen. We also sequence 5 genomes from Endogonales. We discovered a group of intracellular endobacteria, Mollicute-Related Endobactera (MRE), within Mortierellaceae and we characterized their incidence and diversity across isolates. We also characterized the incidence and diversity of Burkholderia-Related Endobacteria (BRE), which we had discovered previously in populations of Mortierellaceae. Through genome sequencing we were able to compare the genomic content of BRE compared to other Burkholderia relatives, and MRE compared to their Mycoplasma relatives. In both cases we documented genome streamlining and reduced central metabolism capability including the ability to synthesize amino acids and carbohydrates. In the case of BRE, we show uniquely acquired specialized metabolism of BRE may provide their fungal host with fitness advantages to defend against soil microfauna preditors. In the case of MRE, we demonstrate extreme genome contraction representing the smallest genome sizes (227KB) known for fungal endosymbionts that includes reduced protein coding content, protein size, and even the loss of DNA repair mechanisms.

We were able to show that Mortierellaceae fungi interact with a diverse range of photosynthetic lineages including red and green algae, non-vascular plants such as mosses and ferns, grasses and angiosperms. In many cases the colonization of plants with these fungi altered plant phenotypes, including the promotion of aboveground growth and seed production. In addition, we generated meta-transcriptomic data from these experiments that included plant-only controls, plant-fungi, and plant-fungi-bacteria (MRE and/or BRE) treatments for Nannochloropsis oceanica (an ochrophyte), Chlamydomonas reinhardtii (a green algae), Physcomitrium patens (a moss), Ceratopteris richardii (a fern), Sorghum bicolor (a grass) and Arabidopsis thaliana (an angiosperm). While the impact of endobacteria was not related to plant phenotypes phenotypes, endobacteria colonizing fungal symbionts were found to impact plant transcriptional responses.

Through this project we also completed novel methodological research and development to enable more accurate reconstruction of co-phylogenies involving symbiotic organisms, and we have applied our methodologies on fungi and their endobacteria and other important models of symbiosis such as bobtail squid and their bioluminescent bacterial symbionts.

Finally, through this project we published >62 peer-reviewed publications and we trained 14 graduate students, provided research experiences to 22 undergraduates (including 7 REUs), 1 high school student, mentoring of 2 post-doctorates, and training of 2 international scholars.
